C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Walk to the side to check maps, and if the train is packed, fold the stroller if possible (or keep it tight by the door).
D: Quick Note to Remember: Stopping suddenly can stress locals out—it messes up the walking flow! :)

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Encourage kids to use their quiet voices. No phone speaker or FaceTime while on the train, ever.
D: Quick Note to Remember: Locals appreciate the quiet time on their commute.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Wear backpacks on your chest in crowded trains. If you sit in a Priority Seat, be ready to stand up immediately for someone who needs it.
D: Quick Note to Remember: It's all about making space for everyone.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Loud running or climbing is a no-go. For tiny spots (ramen/sushi counters), it's normal to be turned away due to lack of stroller space.
D: Quick Note to Remember: Don't take it personally—it's usually just about the small space!

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Use the payment tray for cash/cards (don't hand it directly). Try not to customize orders heavily; Japan is less flexible.
D: Quick Note to Remember: Keep things simple and you’ll make the staff happy.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Stick to places that are mostly food (brighter, families present) in the early evening. Skip the dim, standing-only "bar" vibes.
D: Quick Note to Remember: If it smells like smoke (喫煙), just leave and find another place (禁煙 = no smoking).

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Step aside to finish food before walking again. Bring a small trash bag—public bins are rare (convenience store bins are technically just for store purchases).
D: Quick Note to Remember: It’s a very clean culture, and you’re helping keep it that way.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Use the umbrella stands or bags provided at shop entrances. Keep the tip low and close—no swinging them at kid-height!
D: Quick Note to Remember: Dripping umbrellas inside is the number one rainy-day annoyance!

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Never wear *any* shoes on the tatami floor, not even your clean hotel slippers. Socks or bare feet only.
D: Quick Note to Remember: This preserves the delicate straw mats.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Wash thoroughly before entering the water. No towels in the bath itself, and keep voices very low.
D: Quick Note to Remember: If kids are too splashy, look for a private/family bath!

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: Teach your kids to freeze in place and find a uniform (staff, police). Keep a card with your hotel info and the phrase: “May-go desu. Tasukete kudasai.” (I am lost. Please help me.)
D: Quick Note to Remember: Japanese people are wonderful at helping lost children.

C: Practical Tip for Your Family: A small nod and "Arigatou!" (thank you) from a child instantly unlocks smiles. Use “Sumimasen” (Excuse me/Sorry) constantly.
D: Quick Note to Remember: These little phrases make a huge positive difference.
